channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine’s Allies Show Unity at Munich Security Conference
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine says weapons deliveries must be accelerated, telling the audience at a three-day meeting of top political leaders and officials that ‘there is no alternative to speed.’
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times

item.title: How a Tiny NATO Nation Tackled a Big Problem: Arming Ukraine
item.description: Luxembourg’s challenges in buying arms on the open market underscore the struggle to keep Ukraine supplied until sophisticated Western weapons arrive in the spring.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Testing a drone bound for Ukraine at a military facility in Luxembourg this month.

item.title: Why Did a Turkish City Withstand the Earthquake When Others Crumbled?
item.description: Erzin survived last week’s 7.8-magnitude quake with no casualties and little damage. The mayor credited his enforcement of building standards, but scientists say it is more likely about geology.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht and Nimet Kirac
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A damaged mosque and minaret in Erzin, Turkey, on Tuesday.

item.title: A Russian Mole in Germany Sows Suspicions at Home, and Beyond
item.description: A director at Germany’s spy service was picked up on suspicion of passing intelligence to Russia. German officials and allies worry just how deep the problem goes.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon and Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Ingmar Nolting for The New York Times
item.media:description: The small Bavarian town of Weilheim, where a director of Germany’s spy agency lived and was arrested in December on suspicion of spying for Russia.

item.title: ‘Machismo Kills’: A Surge in Murders of Women Alarms Spain
item.description: The government is under pressure to combat gender violence after what authorities say were the killings of at least eight women this year by former or current partners.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and José Bautista
item.media:description: Members of the feminist group Femen protest in Madrid last month against the killings of Spanish women by men. The government has promised to take steps like creating checkpoints at health centers where women can report violence.

item.title: South Africa and Russia Are Old Friends. A War Isn’t Going to Change That.
item.description: South Africa is set to start joint naval drills with Russia and China, despite criticism from American, European and even some South African officials that it looks like an endorsement of Russia’s Ukraine war.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: The Russian military frigate ‘Admiral Gorshkov’ docked in the harbor of Cape Town on Monday in advance of an 11-day joint maritime drill being staged with South Africa and China.

item.title: 18 Migrants Found Dead in Truck in Bulgaria
item.description: The dead appeared to have suffocated inside a secret compartment under a load of lumber.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: Police officers at the site where at least 18 migrants were found dead in an abandoned truck near Sofia, Bulgaria, on Friday.

item.title: ‘The World’s Largest Construction Site’: The Race Is On to Rebuild Ukraine
item.description: As the country’s leaders lay postwar plans, companies from around the world are jockeying for advantage in what could be a multibillion-dollar effort, although one loaded with risk.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen and Liz Alderman
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: Some estimates put the cost of rebuilding Ukraine’s physical infrastructure as high as $750 billion.

item.title: Syria’s Assad Uses Disaster Diplomacy to Inch Back Onto World Stage
item.description: “A tragedy for Syrians is a boon for Assad because nobody else wants to manage this mess,” one analyst said of President Bashar al-Assad, who became a global pariah for his regime’s abuses during a civil war.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:description: A portrait of President Bashar al-Assad along a road where vehicles transport aid for earthquake victims, at the Iraq-Syria border.

item.title: Divided Views of Nicola Sturgeon Among Scots Reflect Wider Political Schism
item.description: Nicola Sturgeon’s resignation was a moment for voters to take stock of her eight years as first minister and reflect on what may come next.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Nicola Sturgeon, announcing her resignation as first minister of Scotland in Edinburgh on Wednesday, cited personal and political reasons as factors in her decision to step down.

item.title: Nicola Sturgeon Resigns: What to Know, and What’s Next for Scotland
item.description: The decision by Ms. Sturgeon to step down as the country’s leader came as a shock. What is her legacy, and why did she quit?
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nicole Sturgeon, as leader of the Scottish National Party, was Scotland’s first minister for over eight years.

item.title: Behind the Balloon Is China’s Push for Business to Serve the Military
item.description: The Chinese government has tried to meld its military and civilian innovation, prompting a backlash from the United States.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Chris Buckley
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A building of the Eagles Men Aviation Science and Technology Group in Beijing. The company was one of several Chinese entities the Biden administration cut off from American parts and technologies for helping develop China’s spy balloons.

item.title: New Zealand, Battered by a Record Storm, Faces a Painful Cleanup
item.description: Six people were dead and thousands were still unaccounted for after Cyclone Gabrielle lashed the North Island.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Flooding in Napier, on the North Island of New Zealand, after Cyclone Gabrielle.

item.title: Thousands of Chinese Retirees Protest Government Cuts to Benefits
item.description: The protest in Wuhan highlights the strain on the finances of local governments, made worse by heavy spending on “zero Covid” measures.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher, Daisuke Wakabayashi and Claire Fu
item.media:description: Demonstrators outside Zhongshan Park in Wuhan, China, on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. and China Vie in Hazy Zone Where Balloons, U.F.O.s and Missiles Fly
item.description: American officials are worried China is far along in developing military technology that operates in the unregulated high-altitude zone of “near space.”
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: U.S. military commanders, lawmakers and policy experts say they fear China has pulled ahead of the United States in thinking strategically about how to use “near space” and in deploying assets there.

item.title: New technology, same old blind spot?
item.description: Don’t just look at what technology can do, look at what it helps people do to each other.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Microsoft’s new Bing search engine using A.I. is demonstrated to media at their campus in Redmond, Washington, in February.

item.title: Eileen Sheridan, Who Dominated Cycling in Postwar Britain, Dies at 99
item.description: Known as “the Mighty Atom,” she excelled at long-distance time trials and set several records that still stand more than 70 years later.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:description: Eileen Sheridan in 1951. Though she was a physically gifted cyclist, she seemed driven less by competitive ambition than by the sheer joy of the ride.

item.title: A Timeline of Nicola Bulley’s Disappearance
item.description: Nicola Bulley, a 45-year-old mother, was last seen on Jan. 27 outside a village in northwestern England. Her disappearance has led to national headlines and rampant speculation on social media.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: Nicola Bulley disappeared from a park in northwestern England late last month.

item.title: Ex-Worker at U.K. Embassy in Berlin Is Sentenced to 13 Years in Prison for Spying for Russia
item.description: The former security guard, who was caught in an undercover operation, had pleaded guilty to passing secret information to the Russian authorities.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:credit: Metropolitan Police Service, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A still, from a hidden camera at the security kiosk in the British Embassy in Berlin, of David Ballantyne Smith taking video of CCTV monitors in 2021. He was a security guard at the embassy at the time.

item.title: Pandemic Closures, Unpatrolled Beach Visits Blamed for Spike in Drownings
item.description: The number of drownings nationwide last summer exceeded the 10-year average by 44 percent, while New South Wales is presently having “one of our worst summers on record.”
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Surfers enjoying the waves at Bondi Beach in Sydney, Australia, on Friday.

item.title: Ron DeSantis Wants to Make Colleges More Conservative
item.description: Conservatives are trying to do to higher education what they did to the news media and think tanks.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:description: Ron DeSantis. Florida’s governor.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Russian missiles on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: About half of the missiles breached Ukraine’s defense system, its president said.

item.title: Russia Hits Ukraine With New Missile Barrage
item.description: In a blend of the old school and the new, Moscow sent balloons over Ukraine before pummeling it with high-tech weaponry.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: A funeral in Lviv on Thursday for a Ukrainian soldier who was killed by a sniper in the city of Bakhmut.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: U.FO.s Were Likely Not Spying, Biden Says
item.description: Also, New Zealand’s recovery from Cyclone Gabrielle and a disturbing conversation with a chatbot.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden delivering remarks on the recent aerial objects at the White House in Washington, on Thursday.

item.title: If Scotland’s Admired Leader Could Not Deliver Independence, Can Anyone?
item.description: The separatist movement needs a new chief after the surprise resignation of Nicola Sturgeon, Scotland’s popular leader, but none of the contenders has anything like her stature.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A demonstration in support of Scottish independence in Glasgow in 2021.

item.title: Belarus Would Join Russia’s War if Ukraine Attacked, Lukashenko Says
item.description: President Aleksandr Lukashenko of Belarus has been surrounded by speculation that his country could be pressed into providing more support for Russia.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus attended joint military exercises with Russia at a training site near Asipovichy, Belarus, shortly before Russia invaded Ukraine last year.

item.title: Spain Allows Legal Gender Change Without a Medical Evaluation
item.description: A new law will allow people 16 and older to change their registered gender without undergoing psychological and medical evaluations to show gender dysphoria.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and José Bautista
item.media:description: L.G.B.T.Q. activists in Madrid on Thursday celebrated the final approval of a law making it easier for people to legally change their gender.

item.title: Arne Treholt, 80, Dies; Diplomat Convicted of Spying for Soviets
item.description: A Norwegian, he handed over NATO plans and other secrets in one of the Cold War’s biggest espionage scandals. He was sentenced to 20 years in prison.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:credit: Norwegian Special Branch Police/SCANPIX, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Arne Treholt, left, chief press officer for the Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs, was photographed in 1983 with two K.G.B. officers, Gennady Titov, center, and Aleksandr Lopatin. A year later Mr. Treholt was arrested on espionage charges.

item.title: Balloons Are Latest Example of Old Tactics Used in Ukraine War
item.description: The Soviet military often used unpowered balloons before World War II, and they made a resurgence in the Cold War. Now they’re being used in the Ukraine war, along with other low-tech devices.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: Unpowered balloons were a feature of the Cold War, including when the Soviet Union accused the United States of deploying aerial reconnaissance balloons over Russia in 1956.

item.title: ‘This Is a Secret’
item.description: A Times columnist spoke with a chatbot powered by artificial intelligence. It didn’t go well.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Microsoft introducing their new Bing search engine using A.I. earlier this month.

item.title: After Going Gray, Lisa LaFlamme Found Herself the Focus of the Story
item.description: Lisa LaFlamme was dismissed after a decades-long TV career, not long after she stopped dyeing her hair, setting off debates across Canada about sexism, ageism and going gray.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lisa LaFlamme, a prominent Canadian TV anchor, let her hair go gray during the pandemic when hair salons shut down. Months later, she lost her job.

item.title: Waffles, Gentle Slopes and Cloudberries Everywhere: Skiing in Sälen, Sweden
item.description: Gstaad it’s not, but this snowy region within driving distance of Stockholm has welcoming cabins deep in the forest, trails for every level of skier and a possibility of gnomes.
item.dc:creator: Danielle Pergament
item.media:credit: David B. Torch for The New York Times
item.media:description: A snowmobiler makes the trip to Hemfjällsstugan, a cabin offering waffles and more, which lies about three miles from the closest road near the Swedish town of Sälen.

item.title: Russia Has Lost Half Its Tanks in Ukraine War, Report Says
item.description: A report by the International Institute for Strategic Studies said Russia’s tank and artillery fleets had suffered “significant attrition” in the war.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A destroyed Russian tank on the side of the road near in Oskil, Ukraine, last year.

item.title: Scientists Wondered if Warming Caused Argentina’s Drought. The Answer: No.
item.description: Climate change didn’t make the dry spell more likely, researchers found, though extreme heat probably made it hurt more.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:description: A cornfield outside Buenos Aires in January. The drought became especially severe in the last three months of 2022.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: The limitations of Russia’s military.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Ukrainians with an anti-tank weapon on the front line in Bakhmut.

item.title: Moscow’s Military Capabilities Are in Question After Failed Battle for Ukrainian City
item.description: A disastrous Russian assault on Vuhledar, viewed as an opening move in an expected spring offensive, has renewed doubts about Moscow’s ability to sustain a large-scale ground assault.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: Ukrainians with an anti-tank weapon on the front line in Bakhmut on Wednesday.

item.title: Who Was Pablo Neruda and Why Is His Death a Mystery?
item.description: After a decade-long investigation, a team of forensic experts issued their final report on the exhumed remains of the acclaimed Chilean poet. Here’s why there are so many questions around his death.
item.dc:creator: Flávia Milhorance
item.media:description: Mr. Neruda in Paris in 1971.

item.title: Was Pablo Neruda Murdered?
item.description: There has long been suspicion that Chile’s military dictatorship poisoned the nation’s most famous poet. A decade-long investigation has produced tantalizing clues, but nothing more.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:description: Pablo Neruda in Paris after being awarded the 1971 Nobel Prize for Literature. He is widely regarded as one of the greatest poets of the 20th century.

item.title: How Questions Over a Spy Balloon and U.F.O.s Fed a Crisis Between the U.S. and China
item.description: U.S. officials now suspect that the balloon was sent to spy on bases in Guam and Hawaii and that other downed objects were not surveillance machines. Washington’s evolving view reflects U.S. and Chinese difficulties in discerning each other’s intentions.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Julian E. Barnes and Adam Entous
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Biden administration officials say the balloon was designed to spy on the United States and other nations.

item.title: Hans Modrow, 95, Dies; One of East Germany’s Last Communist Leaders
item.description: He became prime minister less than two weeks after the fall of the Berlin Wall, and initially sought to preserve East Germany before accepting reunification.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Hans Modrow in 1993. Within East Germany’s rigid Communist Party, he was widely seen as a reformer in the mold of the Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

item.title: Corruption Trial of Mexico Ex-Lawman Goes to Jury
item.description: As the case of Genaro García Luna, Mexico’s former top security official, ended with closing statements, the jury will consider the credibility of criminals who testified against him.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer and Nate Schweber
item.media:description: A protester outside the courthouse in Brooklyn where closing arguments in the trial of Genaro García Luna, Mexico’s former public security secretary, were held on Wednesday.

item.title: Nicola Sturgeon Resignation Hints at Shifting Norms for Women
item.description: In announcing her plans to leave office, Nicola Sturgeon spoke to Scots about the personal toll being in politics can take.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: First Minister Nicola Sturgeon of Scotland in Edinburgh, announcing that she will stand down.

item.title: Ukraine Says It Shot Down Russian Balloons Over Kyiv
item.description: Russia “uses such flying objects for reconnaissance or to confuse air defense systems,” Yuriy Ihnat, the spokesman for the Ukrainian air force,
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar and Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kyiv, Ukraine, in September.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: 1.5 Million Covid Deaths in China?
item.description: Also, Scotland’s leader resigns and Air India orders a record 470 planes.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg

item.title: Nicola Sturgeon Resigns as Scotland’s First Minister, Citing Toll of the Job
item.description: Nicola Sturgeon’s resignation removes one of the most formidable figures from British politics, one who has dedicated her life to the cause of Scottish independence.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Jenny Gross
item.media:description: Nicola Sturgeon in Edinburgh after announcing on Wednesday that she would stand down as first minister of Scotland.

item.title: World Bank President, Dogged by Climate Questions, Will Step Down Early
item.description: David Malpass, under fire for months by critics who accused him of climate denialism, said he would resign in June, a year before his term ends.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.media:description: David Malpass was nominated in 2019 by President Donald J. Trump.

item.title: What Toxic Chemicals Were Aboard the Derailed Train in Ohio?
item.description: The train was carrying industrial materials used in plastics, paint thinners and other products, according to information provided to the federal government.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.category: Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry
item.media:credit: Ohio National Guard, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Workers prepare to enter the area where the disaster took place.

item.title: Israeli Parliament Votes to Deport Citizens Convicted of Terrorism
item.description: Amid a surge in violence, lawmakers voted to allow the authorities to deport convicted Palestinians, including Israeli citizens, who also receive money from the Palestinian Authority for their actions. Opponents called the law, aimed at Arabs, discriminatory.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Israeli security forces at the entrance to East Jerusalem’s Shuafat refugee camp after a stabbing attack on Monday.

item.title: Thief Steals Nearly 200,000 Cadbury Creme Eggs in Britain
item.description: Unable to resist jokes, the police credited themselves with having “helped save Easter” by solving the “eggs-travagent” crime.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:description: Cadbury Creme Eggs on display in a shop in Birmingham, England. A man admitted to stealing about 200,000 of the eggs, worth about $37,000.

item.title: Small English Town Gets Musical in Search for New Doctor
item.description: The Cornish village of Lostwithiel is looking for a new general practitioner amid a national shortage of primary care doctors. They hope a music video will do the trick.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward

item.title: Two Teenagers Charged in Murder of Brianna Ghey in England
item.description: The police said two 15-year-olds were charged with murder on Wednesday after Brianna Ghey, a transgender 16-year-old, was found fatally stabbed in a park.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:description: More than two dozen vigils are planned for Brianna Ghey this week in the United Kingdom.

item.title: Who Could Replace Nicola Sturgeon as Scotland’s First Minister?
item.description: Ms. Sturgeon’s party, the Scottish National Party, is expected to hold an election to choose her successor in the coming weeks.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia

item.title: Scientists Get a Close-Up Look Beneath a Troubling Ice Shelf in Antarctica
item.description: A robot lowered through the ice reveals how the Thwaites shelf is melting, which will help forecast its effect on global sea level.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain

item.title: Before Stepping Down, Nicola Sturgeon Faced a Battle Over Transgender Rights
item.description: The fight didn’t propel Nicola Sturgeon to resign, she said, but it did lead to a clash with the British government.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Nicola Sturgeon, Scotland’s first minister, was repeatedly quizzed at a news conference about whether she regarded Isla Bryson, a transgender woman who was convicted of rape before her transition, as a man or a woman.

item.title: China Says U.S. Flew Balloons Over Xinjiang and Tibet
item.description: The accusation came days after Beijing claimed that the United States had sent airships over China multiple times, ramping up tensions between the two superpowers.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.media:description: A photograph provided by the U.S. Navy showing sailors recovering a balloon in the waters off South Carolina this month.

item.title: How Does Scotland Fit Into the UK Government?
item.description: In Scotland, the government makes decisions relating to the economy, education, health, justice and other areas.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: Bute House, the official residence of the first minister of Scotland, in Edinburgh.

item.title: In Turkey After the Earthquake, Hope Fades for Waiting Families
item.description: Residents of Adiyaman, hit hard by the quake, hold impromptu vigils while they await news of relatives still under the rubble, feeding wood from shattered cupboards into fires to keep warm.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard, Safak Timur and Emin Ozmen
item.media:credit: Emin Ozmen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourning after rescuers found the body of a relative in a collapsed building in Adiyaman, Turkey, on Tuesday.

item.title: Russia’s losses around Vuhledar renew questions about its ability to sustain a fresh offensive.
item.description: The fighting has also come at a cost for Ukraine, which is expending vast amounts of ammunition to repel Russia’s growing numbers of ground troops,
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: An aerial view of the city of Vuhledar this month.

item.title: 6,000 Ukrainian Children Are Being Held in Russian Camps, Report Finds
item.description: Children as young as four months old are being held in “integration programs” designed to Russify them, according to researchers.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Thai Cave Survivor Dies in England
item.description: Duangphet Promthep was a member of the soccer team that escaped from a submerged cave in Thailand in 2018, and he later attended a soccer academy in England. The cause of his death was unclear.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:description: Duangphet Promthep, one of the boys rescued from the flooded cave in northern Thailand, with relatives after his return home in 2018.

item.title: Who Is Nicola Sturgeon, Scotland’s Longest-Serving First Minister?
item.description: Nicola D
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nicola Sturgeon, the first minister of Scotland, said she would resign from her position of more than eight years.
